thread.title: Drone video service set to launch at Winter Park, Copper Mountain
thread.title_full: Drone video service set to launch at Winter Park, Copper Mountain - The Denver Post

author: Jason Blevins
title: Drone video service set to launch at Winter Park, Copper Mountain
text:
A California start-up with $10 million in venture capital funding has partnered with Copper Mountain and Winter Park ski areas to offer drone video services this season.
Cape Productions on Tuesday announced nine resorts — including Copper and Winter Park — as partners in the company's plan to deliver drone-captured video to ski resort visitors.
"All you have to do is go to any liftline and count the GoPros mounted to helmets to see the demand for this individualized video capturing," Winter Park spokesman Steven Hurlbert said. "This drone video is certainly the next step in that demand."
But don't expect the skies to be buzzing with camera-toting quadcopters at either resort.
While precise plans have yet to be formed, the commercial operations at Winter Park and Copper likely will be limited to specific areas — or drone zones.
"We are sort of working out the kinks rights now in terms of location on the hill but we are looking at a general run where guests will be able to go down and get this drone footage and this cool video," Copper Mountain spokeswoman Stephanie Sweeney said.
Advertisement Cape Productions CEO and co-founder Jason Soll, who is backed by investors including the world's largest venture capital firm New Enterprise Associates, estimates drone-video packages will run about $150. That would include three runs with the drone hovering overhead and a 90-second to 2-minute highlight video, edited and e-mailed to customers. The drones fly on virtual guide wires that prevent them from hitting obstacles like trees or chairlifts while avoiding crowded areas.
Both Copper Mountain and Winter Park have signed one-year agreements with Cape Productions.
The company filmed training sessions with the U.S. Ski Team in New Zealand this summer.
"The unique camera angles we got and the stunning footage provided our coaches and athletes with a great experience and those images sent to our fans inspired us all," U.S. Ski and Snowboard Association spokesman Michael Jaquet said in a statement announcing Cape Productions' resort plan.
Winter Park initially forged the deal with Cape Productions hoping to test the system in summer at the famed Trestle Bike Park — with one rider at a time flying down a designated trail. But the wait for Federal Aviation Administration and the U.S. Forest Service approvals pushed back launch.
"We don't really have our heads quite around how it would work in the winter," Hurlbert said.
Cape Productions is working with the FAA and the Forest Service on what would be the country's first-ever commercial drone permit at ski areas. Soll said he hopes to get that final approval from the FAA in the next few weeks and then will announce start dates at resorts.
The Forest Service will oversee the resorts' commercial drone policies through annual operating plans submitted to the agency.
Cape Productions carries a $5 million insurance policy at each ski area.
The FAA is still mulling updated regulations on drones but its proposed regulations allow exemptions for nearly 2,000 drone operators who cannot fly drones within 500 feet of the public, which pretty much eliminates the idea of drones at open-to-the-public ski resorts.
Copper Mountain and Winter Park ban individuals from using drones.
The National Conference of State Legislators says 45 states have considered 166 bills regulating drones so far in 2015 and 20 states have passed 26 laws addressing drones.
Winter Park isn't sure if it will designate a particular run for drone video or use it in the terrain park, or maybe for young racers on its heavily-used race course. The resort also is pondering more practical uses for drones, like lift inspections.
"It's fun to explore. It's fun that we have this technology and it's fun to even consider and think of all the possibilities," Hurlbert said. "The applications are just everywhere."
